instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I check and i don't see any sign of liquid in this board.
I have short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7140 - Pin 2).
I plugged the charger and check if i can find some warm component, no luck...
So, i inject Voltage on F7140 pin 2 and nothing happen, but i notice the cable i use for inject voltage start get warm.

I removed:
- <RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR>
- <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>
- <RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR>
- <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>
- L7130
- <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>

No luck. The short still there.

Do you guys have any hint for me?

Thank you

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Something must heat up. Is there a short on CPU Vcore?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes, i know, but nothing gets warm on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
So, on PPVCC S0 CPU (<CAPACITOR>C1096</CAPACITOR>) Pin 1 i get 13.8Ω

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Inject voltage on PPBUS, something must get hot, nothing else to say.

threads.message: you can have a short but when you inject 12v on ppbus, how many amps/current is actually going in? 0.2a? 1a? 2a? or 0a?
